title: Guarantor responsibility in a Debt collection
question: I was a guarantor for my friend’s apartment, but he ended up dropping out from college and left a big debt ($3500) behind. I understand that I am legally responsible for the debt even though my friend and I weren’t sharing the apartment.
answers:
Do not believe anything that a debt collector tells you or promises you. Do you want the account reported as a "paid collection", settled for less than the full amount owing? You should get a copy of your credit reports from each of the 3 credit bureaus. (annualcreditreport.com for free, really free reports, one time each year.) See who is actually reporting the account. If it was the original creditor, and you are dealing with a debt buyer or someone without authority to remove the account ("delete tradeline" reported to CRA), you have a credit ding.

Is the collector threatening to sue you? And bring their witnesses to court? Can the collector itemize the amount claimed? Was it rent during the time the apt was occupied? Was it "damages" for a period after he moved out? If so, when the the landlord re-rent the apt? What efforts did it use to find a new tenant?

Yo should consult a debt collection defense attorney to finalize the paperwork of any settlement.

Provided the offer is put in writing, I see nothing wrong with it. You need to make sure that the collection agency is authorized to act for the original creditor and know how this will be reported on your credit (you want it shown as paid in full, not compromised). I *strongly* recommend speaking with an attorney before you do anything.

There are a few items that a lawyer should know before advising you on your debt situation. First, did you sign the lease or rental agreement or a guarantee form with the landlord? Second, did the landlord or the collection agency file a lawsuit against you or your former roommate? Third, if no lawsuit was filed on this lease, when did you last make a payment on this debt? If they have nothing in writing from you, then you may not owe the debt at all and you should not pay or offer to pay anything. I say may, because it's amazing what documents people forgot they signed.

I have a blog on my "Don't Pay a Dime Strategy," which may apply to your situation. See link below. Essentially, if you don't make any payments for longer than the statute of limitations period, then the debt is no longer your legal obligation, so it is not something to payoff, because in a few more years, it should no longer appear on your credit report. Essentially, federal law permits debts to be reported no longer than 7.5 years from date of delinquency, which is typically the month after you stopped paying it. The major exception is if there is a lawsuit that was previously filed, but has not been fully satisfied, which can be reported until it is satisfied, discharged, or expires. If a debt is disputed, it may be removed from credit reports even earlier if it cannot be verified.

Before paying anything, I would consult a debt collection DEFENSE attorney. It may not only save you money now, but it may save you from having to pay the rest of this balance. I am concerned that if they get you to pay and acknowledge half of the debt, they could demand you pay the other half or sue you. If you reach a settlement, be sure it is in writing. My Avvo profile has three legal guides on settlement, including terms that you can use to ensure the settlement is properly documented to avoid problems later.
